unicode.value: How to end a war
Aurelio Cacereño Jiménez

Unidad didáctica para aprender a comprender y componer textos argumentativos, que contribuyen a formar una opinión fundamentada. Contenidos lingüísticos: vocabulario de relaciones y conflictos internacionales, estructuración de textos argumentativos, cultura de potencias anglófonas, "second conditional", "reported speech", opinar a través de "modal verbs".
master class
closed exercise or problem
real project
didactic game
open problem
conceptual map
real or virtual learning environment
Página

Welcome to How to end a war, a unit that will teach you to use English as a tool to solve conflicts with non-Spanish speakers. You will learn to help two people who stopped talking to each other, to correct someone who says something false, and to defend others (or yourself!) when they are innocent.

Tell off = Reñir
Text and Tasks
Think about it...
Enter a question for learners to reflect upon.
Describe how learners will assess how they have done in the exercise (rubrics are useful devices for providing reflective feedback).
University of Auckland

Reflection is a teaching method often used to connect theory to practice. Reflection tasks often provide learners with an opportunity to observe and reflect on their observations before presenting these as a piece of academic work. Journals, diaries, profiles and portfolios are useful tools for collecting observation data. Rubrics and guides can be effective feedback tools.
Enter a question for learners to reflect upon.
Reflective question:

When you were a kid, did you ever have a fight with a friend? Has your father ever told you off unfairly? Sometimes, it's your fault. Sometimes, you’re innocent. Sometimes, both of you did something wrong, right?
Describe how learners will assess how they have done in the exercise (rubrics are useful devices for providing reflective feedback).

The same happens when governments and leaders fight. Conflicts happen every day between people, but also between organizations… and countries. Most of the time, the two parts have a reason to be angry. But that doesn't mean they are right! Remember that.

The same happens when governments and leaders fight. Conflicts happen every day between people, but also between organizations… and countries. Most of the time, the two parts have a reason to be angry. But that doesn't mean they are right! Remember that.
Some recent conflicts that you might have heard about...

Israel-Palestine conflict
About this unit...

In this unit, you will learn how to... 

  • Understand (read and listen) opinions about a conflict.
  • Build and share your own opinion about a conflict, after listening to both parts.
  • Share other people's POV.
  • Explain conflicts to people who want to know more.
  • Ask and answer controversial questions.
Text and Tasks
Objetivos [CASTELLANO]
University of Auckland
Objectives describe the expected outcomes of the learning and should define what the learners will be able to do when they have completed the learning tasks.
Type the learning objectives for this resource.

En esta unidad, vas a trabajar para lograr los siguientes objetivos:

  • Memorizar vocabulario y expresiones relacionados con la política mundial y los conflictos, para ser capaz de aplicarlos a textos reales relacionados.
  • Extraer vocabulario, expresiones y patrones sonoros y escritos de textos orales (una canción y varios vídeos) y escritos (artículos), para poder utilizar la información en situaciones de mediación de conflictos.
  • Aplicar palabras y expresiones aprendidas en ejercicios de huecos, para reforzar su memorización.
  • Analizar la estructura del reported speech y del second conditional, para poder aplicarlo y corregirlo correctamente durante su uso.
  • Utilizar el reported speech y el second conditional en textos de elaboración propria, escrita y oralmente (posts en redes sociales, reflexiones escritas y vídeos grabados) para ser capaz de expresar opiniones o comentarios externos relevantes para un tema, así como para extraer conclusiones y argumentos de soluciones hipotéticas.
  • Descubrir el valor del acceso a conocimiento en varias lenguas a través de internet, lo que permite enriquecer de manera más profunda los conocimientos de un tema de interés personal.
  • Responder a preguntas específicas sobre la guerra de Ucrania, utilizando fuentes fiables y reconociendo su autoría, ayudando a un familiar monolingüe.
  • Responder de manera estructurada y adecuada a comentarios polémicos acerca de temas sensibles, reforzando el trabajo por el diálogo, participando en la búsqueda de una solución pacífica para conflictos como el de la franja de Gaza.ç
  • Analizar un debate sencillo en inglés, valiendose de pista visual y auditiva (vídeo y audio), así como de ayuda textual (subtítulos), para poder aplicarlos en prácticas discursivas personales.
  • Grabar un vídeo exigiendo soluciones a conflictos propios en el aula, participando en la mejora activa de la educación pública.
You should know by now...

Prerequisite knowledge refers to the knowledge learners should already have in order to be able to effectively complete the learning. Examples of pre-knowledge can be:
  • Learners must have level 4 English
  • Learners must be able to assemble standard power tools
Describe the prerequisite knowledge learners should have to effectively complete this learning.

To participate in the activities of this unit, you need to know content from earlier years (1st ESO, 2nd ESO and 3rd ESO). These include:

  1. The first conditional
  2. Modals for obligation and prohibition
  3. Speak about your likes and dislikes
  4. Agree and disagree
  5. All the basic past, present and future tenses.

You will frequently find these in this unit, so make sure that you know how to use them. If you need help, click on the links for reinforcement exercises, ask the teacher for help, or seek yourself on the internet.
1. Introduction – What’s your opinion?
Case Study
University of Auckland
Provide relevant feedback on the situation.

A case study is a device that provides learners with a simulation that has an educational basis. It takes a situation, generally based in reality, and asks learners to demonstrate or describe what action they would take to complete a task or resolve a situation. The case study allows learners apply their own knowledge and experience to completing the tasks assigned. when designing a case study consider the following:
  • What educational points are conveyed in the story
  • What preparation will the learners need to do prior to working on the case study
  • Where the case study fits into the rest of the course
  • How the learners will interact with the materials and each other e.g. if run in a classroom situation can teams be setup to work on different aspects of the case and if so how are ideas feed back to the class
Describe the activity tasks relevant to the case story provided. These could be in the form of questions or instructions for activity which may lead the learner to resolving a dilemma presented.

Create the case story. A good case is one that describes a controversy or sets the scene by describing the characters involved and the situation. It should also allow for some action to be taken in order to gain resolution of the situation.
Case Study
C:\Program Files (x86)\exe\images\empty.gif
What do you think about this operation? Is it fair? Is it good for the people of Venezuela? Is it dangerous?
I've thought about it!

International laws and international organizations exist to stop wars. There are more than 200 countries in the world and the people living in them have very different opinions. Most of these opinions are valid, and we should always try to listen and respect other culture's choices, as long as they do not disrespect our own choices. Wars kill innocent people, and they are usually started because of money, and nothing else.

International laws and international organizations exist to stop wars. There are more than 200 countries in the world and the people living in them have very different opinions. Most of these opinions are valid, and we should always try to listen and respect other culture's choices, as long as they do not disrespect our own choices. Wars kill innocent people, and they are usually started because of money, and nothing else.

Create the case story. A good case is one that describes a controversy or sets the scene by describing the characters involved and the situation. It should also allow for some action to be taken in order to gain resolution of the situation.

In January 2026, the US army entered Venezuela in a major operation. The United States attacked and captured President Nicolás Maduro and his wife. The U.S. government said the action was necessary for security and justice reasons. However, most experts and countries say the operation broke international law.

Who should you believe and support?
The two participants of a conflict may have valid reasons to be angry. You should always think for yourself after listening to both parts. It's best if you investigate and search for evidence.

Read and learn
Reading Activity
University of Auckland

The Reading Activity will primarily be used to check a learner's comprehension of a given text. This can be done by asking the learner to reflect on the reading and respond to questions about the reading, or by having them complete some other possibly more physical task based on the reading.

Teachers should keep the following in mind when using this iDevice:

  1. Think about the number of different types of activity planned for your resource that will be visually signalled in the content. Avoid using too many different types or classification of activities otherwise learner may become confused. Usually three or four different types are more than adequate for a teaching resource.
  2. From a visual design perspective, avoid having two iDevices immediately following each other without any text in between. If this is required, rather collapse two questions or events into one iDevice.
  3. Think about activities where the perceived benefit of doing the activity outweighs the time and effort it will take to complete the activity.
Reading Activity
Enter the details of the reading including reference details. The referencing style used will depend on the preference of your faculty or department.
What to read

A child-friendly guide to the Gaza crisis

At school, home or on social media, you may have heard people talking about Gaza and have wondered, what is happening?
Right now, families are living through a war. Homes, schools and entire neighbourhoods have been damaged or destroyed, and children have been forced to leave everything behind as they flee the violence, often multiple times. For children, this means not only losing the chance to learn and play, but also losing a safe place to sleep at night.

What is the Gaza Strip?

The Gaza Strip is a small area of land in the Middle East, between Israel, the Mediterranean Sea and Egypt. The Gaza Strip is part of the State of Palestine.

The Gaza Strip is a piece of land in the Middle East that sits between Israel and the Mediterranean Sea. It’s called a “strip” because it’s long and narrow – about 40-kilometres which is roughly the size of a large Australian suburb – and home to over 2.3 million people, about half of them children.

What does the ceasefire mean for children in Gaza?
The ceasefire that began on 10 October 2025 gives children and their families a chance to start recovering from two years of conflict and reunite with loved ones. More food, clean water, and essential supplies, such as lifesaving medicine, medical equipment, gas for cooking and tents for shelter, are being allowed in. Humanitarian organisations, like UNICEF, can also reach more children with the urgent support they need, such as lifesaving nutrition, healthcare, clean water, education and protection. 

But a ceasefire doesn’t mean everything is fixed. Many children in Gaza have seen or experienced things no one should ever have to. They’re returning to places where their homes once stood – now reduced to rubble. Every child needs lasting peace so they can go back to school, play, and live without fear. 

How many people, especially children, have been killed or hurt?
Sadly, tens of thousands of people have been killed or injured, and many of them are children. It’s really hard to give an exact number because the situation keeps changing every day, but it does show just how dangerous and unfair the war is on children. Every child has the right to be safe, and that’s why organisations like UNICEF are working hard to protect them and are calling for an end to the fighting so that no more children are hurt or killed.

From https://www.unicef.org.au/unicef-youth/making-sense-of-emergencies/youth-israel-palestine-crisis?

Activity - Listen to the song and aswer the questions
University of Auckland

An activity can be defined as a task or set of tasks a learner must complete. Provide a clear statement of the task and consider any conditions that may help or hinder the learner in the performance of the task.
Describe the tasks the learners should complete.

1. According to the song, you should practice what you preach. This means that you do what you say. For example, your mom tells you "clean and arrange your bedroom" because she cleans and arranges her bedroom. What do you think? Do you practice what you preach to your friends and family?
  2. Look at the following verbs from the song. Make a simple sentence with each one:
    • to respect
    • to kill
    • to care about
  3. Look in the internet for the meaning of to turn the other cheek. Can you think of a similar expression in Spanish? Do you know someone that turns the other cheek when there is a conflict?
Complete the lyrics!

If left unchecked a small number of spelling and capitalization errors will be accepted. If checked only an exact match in spelling and capitalization will be accepted.

For example: If the correct answer is Elephant then both elephant and Eliphant will be judged "close enough" by the algorithm as it only has one letter wrong, even if "Check Capitalization" is on.

If capitalization checking is off in the above example, the lowercase e will not be considered a mistake and eliphant will also be accepted.

If both "Strict Marking" and "Check Capitalization" are set, the only correct answer is "Elephant". If only "Strict Marking" is checked and "Check Capitalization" is not, "elephant" will also be accepted.

Cloze exercises are texts or sentences where students must fill in missing words. They are often used for the following purposes:

  1. To check knowledge of core course concepts (this could be a pre-check, formative exercise, or summative check).
  2. To check reading comprehension.
  3. To check vocabulary knowledge.
  4. To check word formation and/or grammatical competence.

If your goal is to test understanding of core concepts or reading comprehension

Write a summary of the concept or reading long enough to adequately test the target's knowledge, but short enough not to induce fatigue. Less than one typed page is probably adequate, but probably considerably less for young students or beginners.

Select words in the text thatare key to understanding the concepts. Thesewill probably be verbs, nouns, and key adverbs.Choose alternatives with one clear answer.

If your goal is to test vocabulary knowledge

Write a text using the target vocabulary. This text should be coherent and cohesive, and be of an appropriate length. Highlight the target words in the text. Choose alternatives with one clear answer.

If your goal is to test word formation/grammar:

Write a text using the target forms. This text should be coherent and cohesive, and be of an appropriate length. Remember that the goal is not vocabulary knowledge, so the core meanings of the stem words should be well known to the students.

Highlight the target words in the text. Provide alternatives with the same word stem, but different affixes. It is a good idea to get a colleague to test the test/exercise to make sure there are no surprises!
Cloze Activity
Enter any feedback you wish to provide the learner with-in the feedback field. This field can be left blank.
DropDown Activity
Provide instruction on how the dropdown activity should be completed.
Read and complete the following text with words that you have learnt in this unit. There are 2 words from the list that you don't need.

A Conflict Seen from Different Sides

In recent years, a serious conflict has affected the country of Penuria. Fighting began when the national army was sent to control an area where people were protesting against the government. The authorities  forced people to leave the area, and they said the reason was to protect public order, but many citizens disagreed with this explanation.

As the fighting continued, thousands of families had to flee their homes because they are afraid of bombs and fire. Many people looked for shelter in schools, hospitals, or buildings outside the city. After weeks of violence, a big part of the city was transformed into  rubble , and basic services like water and electricity stopped working.

The situation became very controversial internationally, and there are diverse points of view. Some countries supported the government, while others asked for an immediate ceasefire  to protect children's lives. Most experts, however, agree that there is no evidence of protesters breaking the law. They say that the government is being extremely  unfair with their people.

2. Let’s build – Grammar & strategies
Do I really need grammar?

Ah, yes, grammar. That boring thing that we have to study in order to pass the test... do we really need it to learn English?

The main objective of learning English, as with any other language, is to be able to communicate with people that can't speak Spanish. Grammar is the book of rules that we follow to use a language correctly. Can we really speak a language if we don't follow its rules?
Text and Tasks
Case Study
University of Auckland
Provide relevant feedback on the situation.

A case study is a device that provides learners with a simulation that has an educational basis. It takes a situation, generally based in reality, and asks learners to demonstrate or describe what action they would take to complete a task or resolve a situation. The case study allows learners apply their own knowledge and experience to completing the tasks assigned. when designing a case study consider the following:
  • What educational points are conveyed in the story
  • What preparation will the learners need to do prior to working on the case study
  • Where the case study fits into the rest of the course
  • How the learners will interact with the materials and each other e.g. if run in a classroom situation can teams be setup to work on different aspects of the case and if so how are ideas feed back to the class
Describe the activity tasks relevant to the case story provided. These could be in the form of questions or instructions for activity which may lead the learner to resolving a dilemma presented.

Create the case story. A good case is one that describes a controversy or sets the scene by describing the characters involved and the situation. It should also allow for some action to be taken in order to gain resolution of the situation.

Think and answer

To convince someone that Spain is safe, you can share with your American friend the real experience of people that you know (your parents, your teachers, your friends...). To agree or disagree with a solution, you can discuss the possible consequences.

  • Can you share other people's opinion in English?
  • Will you understand your American friend if she speaks about her family's opinion?
  • Can you speak about consequences of a possible solution in English?
I've thought about it!

• In English, we use something called reported speech to speak about other people's opinions and experiences. It's very similar to Spanish "estilo indirecto".
  • When we want to speak about possible future consequences of something, we can use a tool called second conditional.

In this unit, we will learn how to understand and use these two tools.

• In English, we use something called reported speech to speak about other people's opinions and experiences. It's very similar to Spanish "estilo indirecto".
  • When we want to speak about possible future consequences of something, we can use a tool called second conditional.

In this unit, we will learn how to understand and use these two tools.

Create the case story. A good case is one that describes a controversy or sets the scene by describing the characters involved and the situation. It should also allow for some action to be taken in order to gain resolution of the situation.

You are hanging out with a new American friend that came to Spain to study this year at your school. She gives you her phone and says "look at the post of this guy! I can't believe it...".

You look at her phone. It's a video of an angry man shouting. He says horrible things about his experience. He thinks that Spain is a dangerous country where you can't go outside alone. He believes that people should be allowed to carry weapons. He is absolutely wrong! Your city is perfectly safe and his solution is terrible!
Think about it...

Journals, diaries, profiles and portfolios are useful tools for collecting observation data. Rubrics and guides can be effective feedback tools.

I've thought about it!

You can communicate without learning all the strategies in the world. There are many ways to say the same thing. However, if you learn new strategies, you will be able to say more things. If you use few words and sentences, the other person might not understand what you meant. She might even understand the opposite idea!

You can communicate without learning all the strategies in the world. There are many ways to say the same thing. However, if you learn new strategies, you will be able to say more things. Reported speech
What is reported speech?

Reported speech is the language that we use when we tell someone what another person said (or thought!). To do this, we can use direct speech or indirect speech.

Example: Your friend Isabel invites you to her home. But your father grounded you because you recently failed a test.

Your answer to Isabel could be...

  • Direct speech: I can't go, Isabel. My dad said "you're grounded".
  • Indirect speech: I can't go, Isabel. My dad says I'm grounded.

Direct speech is easy to learn, but indirect speech is usually the most natural way to speak. How do we form it?

Verb tenses

To form indirect speech, we first need to take a look at the verb. If the sentence speaks about the present or the future, we don't need to change it. However, if the sentence speaks about the past, we need to adapt what the original person said.

Example: if Isabel is inviting you now...

  1. Isabel asks "Do you want to come over?" (PRESENT)
  2. You ask your dad if you can go out.
  3. He says "You are grounded".
  4. You tell Isabel "Dad says I am grounded".

If Isabel invited you yesterday...

  1. She asks "Why didn't you come yesterday?" (PAST)
  2. Your dad said "You are grounded".
  3. Yo tell Isabel "Dad said I was grounded".

Do you get it?

If we want to pass a sentence about the past to indirect speech, we change the verb tense like this:

Present simple ------------------> Past simple
Present continuous -------------> Past continuous
Present perfect -----------------> Past perfect

We also adapt sentences that were originally in a past tense (for example, if your friend says "I thought you were grounded"). But we won't study that for now.

Examples:

PRESENT PAST
My dad tells me "you are grounded" He told me I was grounded.
My dad tells me "you're not studying". He told me I was not studying.
My dad tells me "you haven't done your homework He told me I hadn't done my homework.

REMEMBER!

Modal verbs also have a past form. We have already studied them.

Examples:

PRESENT PAST
My dad tells me "you can fail the test"

He told me I can fail the test (you still haven't done it).

He told me I could fail the test (you already did the test).
My dad tells me "you will fail the test".

He told me I will fail the test (you still haven't done it).

He told me I would fail the test (you already did the test).

Reflection is a teaching method often used to connect theory to practice. Reflection tasks often provide learners with an opportunity to observe and reflect on their observations before presenting these as a piece of academic work. Enter a question for learners to reflect upon.
Reflective question:

You can say the same message with two completely different sentences. For example, if you want to tell your friend that you can't go shopping with him next Saturday, you can tell him :

  • "I can't, man. I have to study"
  • "I can't, man. I will be studying"

The two sentences say the same message. Of course, there are small differences, but both options are correct. Each person speaks in a different way. That doesn't mean they are wrong. Language is personal. You just have to be sure that the rest of the people understand you!

Activity: Multi-select
University of Auckland

Although more often used in formal testing situations MCQs can be used as a testing tool to stimulate thought and discussion on topics students may feel a little reticent in responding to. When designing a MCQ test consider the following:
  • What learning outcomes are the questions testing
  • What intellectual skills are being tested
  • What are the language skills of the audience
  • Gender and cultural issues
  • Avoid grammar language and question structures that might provide clues

When building an MCQ consider the following:
  • Use phrases that learners are familiar with and have encountered in their study
  • Keep responses concise
  • There should be some consistency between the stem and the responses
  • Provide enough options to challenge learners to think about their response
  • Try to make sure that correct responses are not more detailed than the distractors
  • Distractors should be incorrect but plausible

Reported speech – Adapting information

We've seen that, first of all, you must pay attention to verb tenses so the message makes sense when you pass it to indirect speech. Now, think about the following sentence:

  • My sister said "I have to buy mountain boots in this shop because I need them for tomorrow".

If you pass this sentence to indirect speech and only switch the verb tense, you will have this:

  • My sister said I had to buy mountain boots in this shop because I needed them for tomorrow.

Does it sound right to you? No, it doesn't. Because the sentence is not speaking about you, but about your sister. So you have to make changes for it to make sense. If you think about it, in Spanish we do the same!

Imagine that, a week after, you are speaking to a friend about what your sister said. A correct way to pass this sentence to indirect speech could be:

  • My sister said she had to buy mountain boots in that shop because she needed them for the day after.

As you can see, we must change the following parts:

  • The pronoun (we're speaking about "my sister", so we use "she").
  • The place (We are not in "this shop" at the moment, so we have to speak about a place that is far away. We can say "the shop", "that shop", we can use the name of the shop, etc.
  • The moment (When I'm using reported speech y sister has already gone to the mountain, so she doesn't need the boots for tomorrow).

But what if you met your friend the day after in the same shop you visited with your sister?

Then you could also say:

  • My sister said she had to buy mountain boots in this shop because she needed them for today.

Do you get it?

You are shopping at the mall and you run into a close friend who is shopping too. You have this conversation:

YOU: Hi, Johnny! What are you doing here?
Johnny: Hi, man! I’m looking for a gift for my sister.

YOU: Oh, nice! Do you need any help?
Johnny: No, I don’t need help, but thanks.

YOU: When is her birthday?
Johnny: Tomorrow.

YOU: What are you going to buy?
Johnny: A necklace, probably.

YOU: That sounds great!
Johnny: Thanks! I’ll call you later.

A few days later, another friend asks you about Johnny, and you tell him you met him a few days ago. Read the text below and write ONE missing word. There's only one possible answer.

Cloze exercises are texts or sentences where students must fill in missing words. They are often used for the following purposes:

  1. To check knowledge of core course concepts (this could be a pre-check, formative exercise, or summative check).
  2. To check reading comprehension.
  3. To check vocabulary knowledge.
  4. To check word formation and/or grammatical competence.

If your goal is to test understanding of core concepts or reading comprehension

Write a summary of the concept or reading long enough to adequately test the target's knowledge, but short enough not to induce fatigue. Less than one typed page is probably adequate, but probably considerably less for young students or beginners.

Select words in the text thatare key to understanding the concepts. Thesewill probably be verbs, nouns, and key adverbs.Choose alternatives with one clear answer.

If your goal is to test vocabulary knowledge

Write a text using the target vocabulary. This text should be coherent and cohesive, and be of an appropriate length. Highlight the target words in the text. Choose alternatives with one clear answer.

If your goal is to test word formation/grammar:

Write a text using the target forms. This text should be coherent and cohesive, and be of an appropriate length. Remember that the goal is not vocabulary knowledge, so the core meanings of the stem words should be well known to the students.

Highlight the target words in the text. Provide alternatives with the same word stem, but different affixes. It is a good idea to get a colleague to test the test/exercise to make sure there are no surprises!

Do you understand now how to create indirect speech? Try to practice by thinking about your friends told you in the past. How would you share that information with your family today?
The second conditional
What is the second conditional?

Do you remember the first conditional? We used the first conditional to speak about consequences of a present situation.

Example: If everyone has weapons, Spain will be an unsafe country.

However, we use the second conditional to speak about the consequences of an imaginary present or future situation.

Example: If all the people had weapons, Spain would be an unsafe country.

Formation of second conditional

To create sentences using the second conditional, we need to combine the following parts:

  1. An imaginary action. We use the word "IF" followed by any imaginary action you want to speak about in PAST SIMPLE.
    Structure IF an imaginary action in PAST SIMPLE
    Example If my parents didn't have a car...
  2. A consequence that we think will happen. We use the Subject plus the modal "WOULD" followed by a consequence (in base infinitive, obviously. We already know that, right?).
    Structure WOULD a consequence (in base infinitive).
    Example I would go everywhere on foot.

We can also explain the consequences with modal verbs of obligation or prohibition. Since we have to use WOULD (a past tense), we can't use MUST or CAN.

Examples:

  • If I didn't have a bike, I would have to go everywhere on foot.
  • If I had a bike, I could go everywhere on foot.
  • If my parents were poor, they wouldn't be able to give me an allowance.

Remember!

When we use first and second conditional, we can switch the order of the two parts. We only put a comma between them if the action goes before the consequence.

If I had a bike, I could go everywhere on foot = I could go everywhere on foot if I had a bike

Reflection is a teaching method often used to connect theory to practice. Reflection tasks often provide learners with an opportunity to observe and reflect on their observations before presenting these as a piece of academic work. Journals, diaries, profiles and portfolios are useful tools for collecting observation data. Rubrics and guides can be effective feedback tools.
Enter a question for learners to reflect upon.
Reflective question:

Both first and second conditional can be used to share possible solutions to conflicts. Using the first conditional means that we are speaking about a very real possibility. Using the second conditional means that you are speaking about possibilities that you are just thinking and sharing. Think about it when you want to be clear about your opinion.

We can use reported speech to share actions and consequences that other people shared with you before. If we pass the first conditional to reported speech, we can change the tenses to the past. If we pass the second conditional to reported speech, we don't need to make any change to the tenses.

Try to use indirect speech to share the following sentences with other people:

  • Your dad says "If we entered a war, many innocent people would die".
  • Your teacher says "If I don't set the test this friday, you will be stressed during the weekend".

3. Understanding and mediating
Let's put all into practice

We have learned new vocabulary and tools to help solve conflicts. Are you ready to put your knowledge into practice?

We will now try to use our new tools and knowledge to share opinions with people. Your knowledge of English AND Spanish can help other people that only know one language!
Text and Tasks
Think about it...
Enter a question for learners to reflect upon.
Describe how learners will assess how they have done in the exercise (rubrics are useful devices for providing reflective feedback).
University of Auckland

Reflection is a teaching method often used to connect theory to practice. Reflection tasks often provide learners with an opportunity to observe and reflect on their observations before presenting these as a piece of academic work. Journals, diaries, profiles and portfolios are useful tools for collecting observation data. Rubrics and guides can be effective feedback tools.
Enter a question for learners to reflect upon.
Reflective question:

Has any relative or friend ever asked you the meaning of something? And what about you? How many times have you asked others?

Languages allow us to learn and understand more things from more sites. There are a million books, websites and videos in English that speak about topics that you love!

Of course, you could use an AI translator sometimes, but they can make mistakes that you won't notice... because you don't know English.

If I tell you that a video says something, I might be deceiving you. How can you tell that I'm not telling the truth?
Describe how learners will assess how they have done in the exercise (rubrics are useful devices for providing reflective feedback).
I know!

If you believe someone blindly, you can be easily deceived. The only way to be able to fact-check, is to understand the language used in that video or text.

You don't need to be suspicious about everything, but it's always good to verify things using different sources.

If you believe someone blindly, you can be easily deceived. The only way to be able to fact-check, is to understand the language used in that video or text.

You don't need to be suspicious about everything, but it's always good to verify things using different sources.
Did you know...?

To "mediate" means to help someone understand better another person (or something written or said by another person). When you help your dad to read something he cannot read, you are mediating. But when you help a friend understand that he is wrong about something, you're mediating too!

The person that mediates is called a "mediator".
Text and Tasks
Read and explain
Before you continue...

In this page you can read the wikipedia article about the recent war between Russia and Ukraine. Wikipedia is a public site that anyone can edit, but very controversial articles (like most conflicts) are very well protected and constantly viewed by many people that will instantly correct wrong information. It is a very reliable source if we look for information about a conflict, although it is always a good idea to fact-check everything with other reliable sites.
Text and Tasks
Task - Explain a conflict.

Approx. needed time
00:30
Participants
Individual task

Your mom wants to know more about the Russo-Ukranian war. You want to help her by searching for information, but you know that the English Wikipedia has more information and it's better fact-checked than other Spanish sites.

Look for information in the English article below to answer the following questions IN SPANISH (remember! it's for your mom!). You will get bonus points if you say where you found the information (indirect speech).

Example: La wikipedia en inglés dice que...

  1. ¿Cuándo empezó la guerra? Qué pasó en 2022?
  2. ¿Qué razones dieron los líderes rusos para invadir Ucrania?
  3. ¿Qué regiones son las más importantes del conflicto? ¿Qué está ocurriendo en ellas?
  4. ¿Qué consecuencias ha tenido la guerra en la población de cada país según el experto Paul D'Anieri? 
  5. ¿Qué dijo el experto Oleg Orlov en 2023 sobre la Rusia de Putin?
  6. ¿Crees que la guerra acabaría si Ucrania diera sus regiones a Rusia? ¿Qué consecuencias tendría?
  7. Imagina que eres el presidente de Rusia y estás de acuerdo con sus motivos para invadir Ucrania ¿Qué harías tú? ¿Qué consecuencias crees que tendrían tus decisiones?

Suggestions

  • Use Ctrl+F to search for specific information.
  • Don't copy and paste sentences. Just explain in Spanish what you could understand.
  • You can use a dictionary, but the idea is that you practice English. If you use automatic translators, this activity will be useless for you.
  • You don't have to be sure about everything you say. It's good to have doubts. Just tell your mom "No estoy seguro, pero creo que...".

    The Russo-Ukrainian war began in February 2014 and is ongoing. Following Ukraine's Revolution of Dignity, Russia occupied Crimea and annexed it from Ukraine. It then supported Russian-backed armed groups who started a war in the eastern Donbas region against Ukraine's military. In 2018, Ukraine declared the region to be occupied by Russia.[8] The first eight years of conflict also involved naval incidents and cyberwarfare. In February 2022, Russia launched a full-scale invasion of Ukraine and began occupying more of the country, starting the current phase of the war, the biggest conflict in Europe since World War II. The war has resulted in a refugee crisis and hundreds of thousands of deaths.

    In early 2014, the Euromaidan protests led to the Revolution of Dignity and the ousting of Ukraine's pro-Russian president Viktor Yanukovych. Shortly after, pro-Russian protests began in parts of southeastern Ukraine, while unmarked Russian troops occupied Crimea. Russia soon annexed Crimea after a highly disputed referendum. In April 2014, Russian-backed militants seized towns and cities in Ukraine's eastern Donbas region and proclaimed the Donetsk People's Republic (DPR) and the Luhansk People's Republic (LPR) as independent states, starting the Donbas war. Russia covertly supported the separatists with its own troops, tanks and artillery, preventing Ukraine from fully retaking the territory. The International Criminal Court (ICC) judged that the war was both a national and international armed conflict involving Russia,[9] and the European Court of Human Rights judged that Russia controlled the DPR and LPR from 2014 onward.[10] In February 2015, Russia and Ukraine signed the Minsk II agreements, but they were never fully implemented in the following years. The Donbas war became a static conflict likened to trench warfare; ceasefires were repeatedly broken but the frontlines did not move.

    Beginning in 2021, there was a massive Russian military buildup near Ukraine's borders, including within neighbouring Belarus. Russian officials repeatedly denied plans to attack Ukraine. Russia's president Vladimir Putin voiced expansionist views and challenged Ukraine's right to exist. He demanded that Ukraine be barred from ever joining the NATO military alliance. Ukraine had been officially a neutral country when the conflict began, but because of Russia's attacks it revived plans to join NATO.[11] In early 2022, Russia recognised the DPR and LPR as independent states. While Russian troops surrounded Ukraine, its proxies stepped up attacks on Ukrainian forces in the Donbas.

    On 24 February 2022, Putin announced a "special military operation" to "demilitarize and denazify" Ukraine, claiming Russia had no plans to occupy the country. The Russian invasion that followed was internationally condemned; many countries imposed sanctions against Russia, and sent humanitarian and military aid to Ukraine. In the face of fierce resistance, Russia abandoned an attempt to seize Kyiv in early April. In August, Ukrainian forces began liberating territories in the north-east and south. In September, Russia declared the annexation of four partially occupied provinces, which was internationally condemned. Since then, Russian offensives and Ukrainian counteroffensives have gained only small amounts of territory. The invasion has also led to attacks in Russia by Ukrainian and Ukrainian-backed forces, among them a cross-border offensive into Russia's Kursk region in August 2024. Russia has repeatedly carried out deliberate and indiscriminate attacks on civilians far from the frontline.[12][13][14] The UN Human Rights Office reported that Russia was committing severe human rights violations in occupied Ukraine.[15] The ICC opened an investigation into war crimes and issued arrest warrants for Putin and several other Russian officials. Russia has repeatedly refused calls for a ceasefire.

    Background

    Main article: Russia–Ukraine relations

    Independent Ukraine and the Orange Revolution

    Further information: Russia–NATO relations and Orange Revolution

    After the dissolution of the Soviet Union (USSR) in 1991, Ukraine and Russia maintained ties. In 1994, Ukraine signed the Treaty on the Non-Proliferation of Nuclear Weapons and agreed to give up the former Soviet nuclear weapons in Ukraine.[16][17] In return, Russia, the United Kingdom, and the United States agreed to uphold the territorial integrity and independence of Ukraine through the Budapest Memorandum on Security Assurances.[18][19] In 1997, Russia signed the NATO-Russia Founding Act. It affirmed that "NATO and Russia do not consider each other as adversaries" and would work together.[20] It acknowledged that "NATO has expanded and will continue to expand its political functions".[21] In 1999, Russia was one of the signatories of the Charter for European Security, affirming the right of each state "to choose or change its security arrangements" and to join military alliances if they wish.[22] Several former Eastern Bloc countries joined NATO, partly in response to regional security threats involving Russia. In 2005, Putin said that if Ukraine and other former Soviet states wanted to join NATO, "we will respect their choice, because it is their sovereign right to decide their own defense policy, and this will not worsen relations between our countries".[23] Putin later said Western powers broke promises not to let any Eastern European countries join.[24][25]

    The 2004 Ukrainian presidential election was controversial. During the election campaign, pro-Western opposition candidate Viktor Yushchenko was poisoned by TCDD dioxin;[26][27] he later accused Russia of involvement.[28] The more Russia-friendly candidate Viktor Yanukovych was declared the winner, despite allegations of vote-rigging by election observers.[29] During a two-month period which became known as the Orange Revolution, large peaceful protests successfully challenged the outcome, and the Supreme Court of Ukraine annulled the result due to widespread electoral fraud. A re-run election was won by Yushchenko.[30] The Russian government sees the Orange Revolution as one of the "colour revolutions" in former Soviet states. According to Anthony Cordesman, Russian military officers viewed such "colour revolutions" as attempts by the US and European countries to undermine Russia.[31]

    Russo-Georgian War

    Main article: Russo-Georgian War

    At the 2008 Bucharest summit, Ukraine and Georgia sought to join NATO, but NATO members were split. Western European countries opposed offering Membership Action Plans (MAP) to Ukraine and Georgia, fearing it would unsettle Russia.[32] NATO refused to offer Ukraine and Georgia MAPs, but also issued a statement agreeing that "these countries will become members of NATO" at some point. Putin strongly opposed their NATO membership bids.[33]

    Russia invaded Georgia in August 2008 and took control of the breakaway regions of Abkhazia and South Ossetia, demonstrating Russia's willingness to use military force to attain its political objectives.[34] Political scientist Paul D'Anieri says the United States "was accused of appeasement and naivete" over its reaction to the invasion.[35] The West's weak response in 2008—and later in 2014—contributed to Russia's assessment of Western warnings against 2022 invasion as not serious,[36][37] and, according to political scientist Samuel Ramani, encouraged further Russian aggression.[38]

    Euromaidan and Revolution of Dignity

    Main articles: Euromaidan and Revolution of Dignity

    Viktor Yanukovych won the 2010 Ukrainian presidential election.[39] In early 2013, the Ukrainian parliament overwhelmingly approved of finalising a free trade and association agreement with the European Union (EU).[40] The Kremlin pressured Ukraine to reject this agreement; Russia imposed embargoes on Ukrainian goods and threatened further sanctions. Kremlin adviser Sergey Glazyev warned that Russia might no longer acknowledge Ukraine's borders if the agreement was signed.[41]

    Under pressure from Russia,[42] in November 2013, Ukrainian president Yanukovych suddenly withdrew from signing the agreement.[43] This sparked a wave of massive protests, known as the "Euromaidan". The protesters opposed Russian interference, government corruption, abuse of power, and human rights violations, including new anti-protest laws.[44][45]

    The protests led to the Revolution of Dignity. On 28 January 2014, Ukraine's government resigned. On 18–20 February, more than 100 protesters were killed in clashes with Berkut special riot police; most of them were shot by snipers.[46] On 21 February, President Yanukovych and the opposition leaders signed an agreement to bring about an interim unity government, urgent constitutional changes (which needed to be signed by the president), and early elections. However, Yanukovych secretly fled the capital that evening and did not inform parliament of his whereabouts. The next day, Ukraine's parliament unanimously voted to remove Yanukovych from office. About 73% of the parliament and members of all parties voted to remove him, including members of his own party and of the pro-Russian Communist Party.[47][48][49][50]

    On 27 February, an interim government was established and early presidential elections were scheduled. The following day, Yanukovych resurfaced in Russia and declared that he remained the president of Ukraine. Some political leaders in the mainly Russian-speaking eastern regions declared continuing loyalty to Yanukovych.[48][51]

    Pro-Russian protests

    Main article: 2014 pro-Russian unrest in Ukraine

    From late February 2014, demonstrations by pro-Russian, separatist and counter-revolutionary groups took place in several cities in eastern and southern Ukraine.[52] Most of the protests were in the Donbas region, made up of Donetsk Oblast and Luhansk Oblast. In the last census, the population of the Donbas was about 58% ethnic Ukrainian and 38% ethnic Russian (Donetsk was 57% Ukrainian and 38% Russian, while Luhansk was 58% Ukrainian and 39% Russian).[53] A national survey held in March–April 2014 found that 58% of respondents in the Donbas wanted autonomy within Ukraine and 31% wanted the region to separate from Ukraine.[54] There were smaller protests in Kharkiv and Odesa.

    The first protests were largely native expressions of discontent with the new Ukrainian government.[52][55] On 23 February 2014, Ukraine's parliament adopted a bill to revoke the status of Russian as an official state language. The bill was not enacted, but the proposal caused anger among some Russian speakers in Ukraine.[56] In the last census, 75% of people in Donetsk Oblast and 69% of people in Luhansk Oblast had Russian as their mother tongue, although most Ukrainian citizens spoke both Ukrainian and Russian.[57] These regions mostly consumed Russia-based media, which promoted the narrative that Ukraine's new government was an illegitimate "fascist junta" and that ethnic Russians were in imminent danger.[58][59]

    Russia used the protests to launch a campaign of political warfare, information warfare, and irregular warfare against Ukraine.[55][60] Leaked e-mails and telephone calls later revealed that the Russian state had funded the separatists and had organised separatist protests, mainly through Kremlin advisers Vladislav Surkov and Sergey Glazyev.[61][62][63] Ukrainian authorities arrested local separatist leaders in early March. Those leaders were replaced by men with ties to the Russian security services and Russian business interests.[64]

    On 6 April 2014, hundreds of masked men stormed and seized weapons from the Security Service buildings in the cities of Donetsk and Luhansk.[65] Protesters then stormed and occupied the Donetsk regional government headquarters, raising the Russian flag and demanding a referendum on joining Russia.[66] The next day, the activists held a meeting in the building and proclaimed the "Donetsk People's Republic" an independent state.[65][67] On 29 April, armed pro-Russian activists stormed and occupied the Luhansk regional government headquarters, proclaiming the "Luhansk People's Republic".[68]

    Causes

    According to political scientist Paul D'Anieri, Russia had the following four causes to start its war with Ukraine in 2014, as well as for the 2022 war:[69]

    • Russia's desire to regain control of Ukraine and turn it into a puppet regime.
    • Russia's conception of itself as a great power entitled to a sphere of influence over the former Soviet Republics.
    • The security dilemma in Europe, with Russia perceiving the expansion of NATO as a threat, and other East European states desiring guarantees against Russian expansionism.
    • Democratic Ukraine being perceived by Russia as a political threat to the authoritarian regime in Russia.

    History

    The Russian occupation of Crimea is usually deemed to be the start of the Russo-Ukrainian war. This was followed by the War in Donbas (2014–2022) and then the 2022 Russian invasion of Ukraine, which started the current phase of the war.

    Historiography

    Different start-dates for the conflict have been identified. According to a number of scholars,[70][71][72] the war began with the February 2014 Russian occupation of Crimea, in particular the 27 February storming of the Crimean parliament.[73][74][75] The Ukrainian government declared 26 February the "Day of Resistance to the Occupation of Crimea", as on that day in 2014 a Crimean Tatar rally was held to oppose Russian interference.[76] Some, including political scientist Andreas Umland, prefer 20 February – the day Russia supposedly issued orders to prepare for the invasion of Crimea, which is also the date engraved on the Russian Crimea campaign medal.[77][78] Dutch Professor of Military History, Floribert Baudet, asserted that "Russia's war against Ukraine did not start in 2014 with the annexation of Crimea" because Russia had been subverting Ukrainian sovereignty long before this.[79]

    Analysts also differ over the nature of the conflict. Paul D'Anieri describes "a limited war in 2014, and then [a] much less limited war in 2022".[80] In contrast, Ukrainian-American historian Serhii Plokhy said in 2023 of the then-ongoing war that "I decline the temptation to identify the date of February 24, 2022, as its beginning, no matter the shock and drama of the all- out Russian assault on Ukraine, for the simple reason that the war began eight years earlier, on February 27, 2014".[71]

    Russian annexation of Crimea (2014)

    Main article: 2014 Russian annexation of Crimea
    Further information: Timeline of the Russian annexation of Crimea

    On 27 February 2014, Russian soldiers without insignia began to occupy Crimea.[81][82][83] At first, Russia denied that the soldiers were theirs, instead claiming they were local "self-defense" units. Later, Putin admitted that they were Russian special forces, and said that he decided to "return" Crimea to Russia when the revolution happened.[84] Russia took advantage of the uncertainty in Ukraine immediately after the ousting of Yanukovych.[85]

    The unmarked Russian soldiers seized the Crimean parliament and government buildings, as well as setting up checkpoints to restrict movement and cut off the Crimean peninsula from the rest of Ukraine.[86][87] While the armed men occupied Crimea's parliament, it dismissed the Crimean government and installed a pro-Russian government under Sergey Aksyonov, whose party won only 4% of votes in the last election.[88] Historian Andrew Wilson and journalist Luke Harding called this the "Crimean coup".[89][90] The parliament then announced a referendum on Crimea's status. Russian rebel commander Igor 'Strelkov' Girkin later admitted:

    "Rebels assembled lawmakers to corral them into the hall so that they could vote. I was one of the commanders of those rebels. I saw that from the inside".[88]

    On 1 March, the Federation Council of Russia approved the use of armed force in Ukraine.[91] Ukraine's prime minister, Arseniy Yatsenyuk, said that Russian military intervention would be the beginning of war,[92] and Ukraine's representative told the UN Security Council that Russia was committing "an act of aggression against the state of Ukraine".[93] Unmarked Russian special forces occupied airports and communications centers,[92] and blockaded Ukrainian military bases, such as the Southern Naval Base. Russian commander Strelkov admitted that most Crimean authorities, police and army units remained loyal to Ukraine, even if some were reluctant to carry out Ukrainian authorities' orders.[88] Russian cyberattacks shut down websites of the Ukrainian government, news media, and social media. Cyberattacks also enabled Russian access to the mobile phones of Ukrainian officials and members of parliament, further disrupting communications.[94]

    The referendum was held under Russian occupation on 16 March 2014. According to the Russian-installed authorities, the result was in favour of joining Russia. It annexed Crimea on 18 March 2014. Following this, Russian forces seized Ukrainian military bases in Crimea and captured their personnel. On 24 March, Ukraine ordered its remaining troops to withdraw.[95] On 15 April, Ukraine's parliament declared Crimea temporarily occupied by Russia.[96] Russia militarized the peninsula and made nuclear threats.[97]

    When Russia invaded Crimea, Ukraine was a neutral country under its Constitution, and Ukraine's post-revolutionary government was not seeking NATO membership.[98][99] In response to Russia's annexation and further attacks on Ukraine, some NATO members agreed to begin training the Ukrainian army.[100]

    War in the Donbas (2014–2021)

    Main article: War in Donbas
    For a chronological guide, see Timeline of the war in Donbas.

    In April 2014, the anti-government protests in the Donbas developed into armed conflict between Russian-backed separatists and Ukraine. Russian citizens with links to its security forces had taken control of the separatist movement by this stage. Russia deployed 30,000–40,000 troops near Ukraine's eastern border in early April.[101][59] This military buildup was used to threaten Ukraine and hinder its response to the pro-Russian separatists,[59] forcing the Ukrainian military to divert its forces to the border instead of the Donbas.[59] Russia began a "hybrid" conflict against Ukraine, involving disinformation, irregular fighters, regular Russian troops, and conventional military support.[102][103][104]

    First months of the war

    For a chronological guide, see Timeline of the war in Donbas (2014).

    On 12 April 2014, a heavily-armed paramilitary unit took over Sloviansk and Kramatorsk in Donetsk Oblast.[105][106] They raided the police and Security Service (SBU) buildings, seizing a large amount of weapons, which were given to local pro-Russian separatists.[106] The unit of more than fifty militants wore no insignia and had been sent from occupied Crimea via Russia.[106] They included fighters from Russia and Ukraine,[106][107] commanded by former GRU colonel Igor 'Strelkov' Girkin.[106] In an interview for Russian ultranationalist newspaper Zavtra, he said that this action sparked the war in eastern Ukraine:

    "I'm the one who pulled the trigger of this war. If our unit hadn't crossed the border, everything would have fizzled out, like in Kharkiv or Odesa".[108][109][110]

    The first conflict deaths in the Donbas occurred on 13 April, when the Russian paramilitaries fired on Ukrainian SBU officers outside Sloviansk. Ukrainian officer Gennady Bilichenko[111] was killed and several wounded, while at least one Russian militant was killed.[107][112] In response, on 15 April, the interim Ukrainian government launched an "Anti-Terrorist Operation" (ATO) in the Donbas. However, Ukrainian forces were poorly prepared, and the operation soon stalled.[113] Russian separatist commander Strelkov said that Ukrainian forces were "extremely cautious" at first, as they did not know how Russia would respond.[109] Due to worsening unrest in Donbas, and the Russian military buildup near the border, Ukraine's armed forces reinstated conscription and were put on full alert for an invasion.[114]

    Pro-Russian forces carried out their first civilian killings in the Donbas on 17 April.[115] They kidnapped local councillor Volodymyr Rybak after he tried to re-raise the Ukrainian flag in Horlivka. His body was dumped in a river along with those of Maidan activists Yuri Popravko and Yuri Diakovskyi – all had been tortured and mutilated.[116][117][118] Russian paramilitaries kidnapped more than two dozen people in the first month of the war,[116] including eight OSCE observers[119] and journalists such as Simon Ostrovsky.[116]

    On 5 July 2014, Ukrainian forces re-took Sloviansk and the pro-Russian forces retreated to Donetsk city. Russian commander Igor 'Strelkov' Girkin said that Donetsk was still relatively peaceful until then. He admitted responsibility for the shelling of the city by Ukrainian forces.[109]

    On 17 July 2014, Russian-controlled forces killed 298 civilians when they shot down a passenger aircraft, Malaysia Airlines Flight 17, as it was flying over eastern Ukraine.[120] Investigations and the recovery of bodies began in the conflict zone as fighting continued.[121][122][123]

    By the end of July, Ukrainian forces were pushing into cities, isolating Donetsk and attempting to restore control of the border. By 28 July, the strategic heights of Savur-Mohyla were under Ukrainian control, along with the city of Debaltseve, an important railroad hub.[124] These Ukrainian successes threatened the existence of the DPR and LPR statelets, prompting Russian cross-border shelling targeting Ukrainian troops on their own soil, from mid-July onwards.[125]

    August 2014 Russian invasion

    See also: Battle of Ilovaisk and 2014 Russian cross-border shelling of Ukraine

    By August 2014, Ukrainian forces had regained much of the territory seized by the separatists.[126] Igor Girkin ('Strelkov') urged direct Russian military intervention, and said that the combat inexperience of his irregular forces, along with recruitment difficulties amongst the local population, had caused the setbacks. He stated, "Losing this war on the territory that President Vladimir Putin personally named New Russia would threaten the Kremlin's power and, personally, the power of the president".[127] Strelkov said that in early August, Russian soldiers, supposedly on "vacation" from the army, began to arrive in Donbas.[128] According to Nikolai Mitrokhin's estimates, by mid-August 2014 during the Battle of Ilovaisk, between 20,000 and 25,000 troops were fighting in the Donbas on the separatist side, and only 40–45% were "locals".[129]

    Russia dispatched what it called a "humanitarian convoy" of trucks across the border on 22 August 2014. Ukraine's security service called this a "direct invasion" and said the trucks were being used to move weapons and bring the bodies of Russian soldiers out of Ukraine.[130]

    Russia then began a more direct invasion of the Donbas.[126][131] On 24 August 2014, Amvrosiivka was occupied by Russian paratroopers,[132] supported by 250 armoured vehicles and artillery pieces.[133] On 25 August, a column of Russian military vehicles was reported to have crossed into Ukraine near Novoazovsk on the Azov sea coast. It appeared headed towards Ukrainian-held Mariupol,[134][135][136][137][138] in an area that had not seen pro-Russian presence for weeks.[139] The following day, the Russian Defence Ministry said these soldiers had crossed the border "by accident".[140][141][142] Russian troops captured Novoazovsk[143] and began deporting Ukrainians who did not have an address registered within the city.[144] Pro-Ukrainian anti-war protests took place in Mariupol.[144][145] The UN Security Council called an emergency meeting.[146]

    The Pskov-based 76th Guards Air Assault Division of the Russian Airborne Forces allegedly entered Ukrainian territory in August and engaged in a skirmish near Luhansk,[147][148] suffering 70–80 dead.[149] The Ukrainian Defence Ministry said that they had seized two of the unit's armoured vehicles near Luhansk, and reported destroying another three tanks and two armoured vehicles in other regions.[150]

    The speaker of Russia's upper house of parliament and Russian state television channels acknowledged that Russian soldiers were in Ukraine, but referred to them as "volunteers" fighting for the "Russian world".[151][152] A reporter for Novaya Gazeta, an opposition newspaper in Russia, stated that the Russian military leadership paid soldiers to resign their commissions and fight in Ukraine in the early summer of 2014, and then began ordering soldiers into Ukraine.[153] Russian opposition MP Lev Shlosberg made similar statements, although he said they were "regular Russian troops", disguised as units of the DPR and LPR.[154] After Ukraine captured ten Russian soldiers in Eastern Ukraine, a Russian defence ministry source stated they were in Ukraine "by accident" while patrolling a section of the Russian-Ukrainian border.[155]

    Minsk agreement and continued fighting

    Main articles: Minsk agreements, Battle of Mariupol (September 2014), and Second Battle of Donetsk Airport

    On 3 September 2014, Poroshenko said he and Putin had reached a "permanent ceasefire" agreement.[156] Russia denied this, denying that it was a party to the conflict, adding that "they only discussed how to settle the conflict".[157][158] Poroshenko then recanted.[159][160] On 5 September Russia's Permanent OSCE Representative Andrey Kelin, said that it was natural that pro-Russian separatists "are going to liberate" Mariupol. Ukrainian forces stated that Russian intelligence groups had been spotted in the area. Kelin said 'there might be volunteers over there.'[161] On 4 September 2014, a NATO officer said that several thousand regular Russian forces were operating in Ukraine.[162]

    On 5 September 2014, the Minsk Protocol ceasefire agreement drew a line of demarcation between Ukraine and separatist-controlled portions of Donetsk and Luhansk Oblasts.

    Despite the Minsk ceasefire, sporadic clashes continued around Donetsk International Airport, the last part of Donetsk city held by Ukrainian troops. On 28 September, Russian-backed forces began an offensive to capture the airport. Ukrainian troops were besieged in the terminal and control tower. They were given the nickname "Cyborgs", as they withstood repeated Russian attacks in grim battlefield conditions.[163] The siege lasted throughout winter and most of the airport was destroyed by shelling. Eventually, on 21 January 2015, rebels took the airport with help from Russian special forces.[164]

    On 7 and 12 November, NATO officials reconfirmed the Russian presence, citing 32 tanks, 16 howitzer cannons and 30 trucks of troops entering the country.[165] NATO said it had seen an increase in Russian tanks, artillery pieces and other heavy military equipment in Ukraine and renewed its call for Moscow to withdraw its forces.[166] The Chicago Council on Global Affairs stated that Russian separatists enjoyed technical advantages over the Ukrainian army since the large inflow of advanced military systems in mid-2014: effective anti-aircraft weapons ("Buk", MANPADS) suppressed Ukrainian air strikes, Russian drones provided intelligence, and Russian secure communications system disrupted Ukrainian communications intelligence. The Russian side employed electronic warfare systems that Ukraine lacked. Similar conclusions about the technical advantage of the Russian separatists were voiced by the Conflict Studies Research Centre.[167]

    Ukraine declared the Russian-backed separatist republics to be terrorist organisations.[168]

    Minsk II agreement and battle of Debaltseve

    Further information: Minsk II, Volnovakha bus attack, January 2015 Mariupol rocket attack, and February 2015 Kramatorsk rocket attack

    In January 2015, Donetsk, Luhansk, and Mariupol represented the three battle fronts.[169] Poroshenko described a dangerous escalation on 21 January amid reports of more than 2,000 additional Russian troops, 200 tanks and armed personnel carriers crossing the border. He abbreviated his visit to the World Economic Forum because of his concerns.[170]

    A new package of measures to end the conflict, known as Minsk II, was agreed on 12 February 2015, with a ceasefire due to begin on 15 February.[171]

    Despite the ceasefire, Russian-backed forces launched an offensive on Debaltseve, a strategic town and salient held by Ukrainian forces. By 18 February 2015, the 8,000 Ukrainian troops had been almost surrounded and were forced to retreat from Debaltseve under relentless fire, suffering heavy casualties. Russian-backed rebel leader Alexander Zakharchenko had said his forces would not observe the ceasefire in Debaltseve, claiming it rightfully belonged to them.[172] Ukraine, the EU and the US accused Russia and its proxies of breaking the ceasefire, and said that the Russian military itself took part in the offensive.[173]

    In September 2015 the United Nations Human Rights Office estimated that 8,000 casualties had resulted from the conflict in eastern Ukraine.[174]

    Static war

    For a chronological guide, see Timeline of the war in Donbas (2015), Timeline of the war in Donbas (2016), Timeline of the war in Donbas (2017), Timeline of the war in Donbas (2018), Timeline of the war in Donbas (2019), and Timeline of the war in Donbas (2020).
    See also: Kerch Strait incident

    After the Minsk agreements, there were few changes in territorial control, while the war settled into static trench warfare around the agreed line of contact, marked by artillery duels and special forces operations. Hostilities never ceased for a substantial period of time, but continued at a low level despite repeated attempts at ceasefire. Both sides began fortifying their position by building networks of trenches, bunkers and tunnels.[175][176] The relatively static conflict was labelled "frozen" by some,[177] though fighting never completely stopped.[178][179] Between 2014 and 2022 there were 29 ceasefires, each agreed to remain in force indefinitely. However, none of them lasted more than two weeks.[180]

    US and international officials continued to report the active presence of Russian military in eastern Ukraine, including in the Debaltseve area.[181] In 2015, Russian separatist forces were estimated to number around 36,000 troops (compared to 34,000 Ukrainian), of whom 8,500–10,000 were Russian soldiers. Additionally, around 1,000 GRU troops were operating in the area.[182] Another 2015 estimate held that Ukrainian forces outnumbered Russian forces 40,000 to 20,000.[183] In 2017, on average one Ukrainian soldier died in combat every three days,[184] with an estimated 6,000 Russian and 40,000 separatist troops in the region.[185][186]

    The Battle of Avdiivka erupted on 29 January 2017 and lasted for several days. It saw the biggest and deadliest clashes in over a year, with more than thirty people killed and heavy artillery barrages. It began hours after newly elected US president Donald Trump spoke by telephone with the Russian president Putin. Some in the Ukrainian government believed the Russian-backed rebels were emboldened by Trump's election. Kostiatyn Yeliseieiv, deputy head of the Ukrainian presidential administration, said it was "a test from the Russian side, of the reaction of the new American administration".[187]

    More than 110 Ukrainian soldiers were killed in the conflict in 2019.[188] In May 2019, newly elected Ukrainian president Volodymyr Zelenskyy took office promising to end the war in Donbas.[188] In December 2019, Ukraine and pro-Russian separatists began swapping prisoners of war. Around 200 prisoners were exchanged on 29 December 2019.[189][190][191][192] In December 2019 Ukraine and Russia agreed to implement a ceasefire. The two sides agreed to swap prisoners of war and disengage military forces in several regions. Russia and Ukraine could not agree on the issues of the withdrawal of Russian-backed troops and the elections in the separatist-held regions.[193]

    According to Ukrainian authorities, 50 Ukrainian soldiers were killed in 2020.[194] Between 2019 and 2021, Russia issued over 650,000 internal Russian passports to Ukrainians.[195][196] There were 27 conflict-related civilian deaths in 2019, 26 deaths in 2020, and 25 deaths in 2021, over half of them from mines and unexploded ordnance.[197]

    Prelude to full-scale invasion

    Main article: Prelude to the 2022 Russian invasion of Ukraine

    From March to April 2021, Russia began a major military build-up near the Ukrainian border, followed by a second build-up from October 2021 onward, in both Russia and Belarus.[198] Throughout, Russia said it was only holding military exercises, and Russia's government repeatedly denied it had plans to attack Ukraine.[199][200]

    In early December 2021, following Russian denials, the US released intelligence of Russian invasion plans, including satellite photographs showing Russian troops and equipment near the border.[201] The intelligence reported a Russian list of key sites and individuals to be killed or neutralised.[202] The US released multiple reports that accurately predicted the invasion plans.[202]

    In the months preceding the invasion, Russian officials accused Ukraine of inciting tensions, Russophobia, and repressing Russian speakers. They made multiple security demands of Ukraine, NATO, and other EU countries. On 9 December 2021 Putin said that "Russophobia is a first step towards genocide".[203][204] Putin's claims were dismissed by the international community,[205] and Russian claims of genocide were rejected as baseless.[206][207][208] In a 21 February speech,[209] Putin questioned the legitimacy of the Ukrainian state, repeating an inaccurate claim that "Ukraine never had a tradition of genuine statehood".[210] He incorrectly stated that Vladimir Lenin had created Ukraine, by carving a separate Soviet Republic out of what Putin said was Russian land, and that Nikita Khrushchev "took Crimea away from Russia for some reason and gave it to Ukraine" in 1954.[211]

    During the second build-up, the Russian government demanded NATO end all activity in its Eastern European member states and ban Ukraine or any former Soviet state from ever joining NATO, among other demands.[213] A treaty to prevent Ukraine joining NATO would go against the alliance's "open door" policy and the right of countries to choose their own security,[214] although NATO had made no progress on Ukraine's requests to join.[215] NATO Secretary General Jens Stoltenberg replied that "Russia has no say" on whether Ukraine joins, and that "Russia has no right to establish a sphere of influence to try to control their neighbors".[216] NATO offered to improve communication with Russia and discuss limits on missile placements and military exercises, as long as Russia withdrew troops from Ukraine's borders,[217] but Russia did not withdraw.

    Escalation in the Donbas

    Further information: Timeline of the war in Donbas (2021) and Timeline of the war in Donbas (2022)

    While Russian troops massed on Ukraine's borders, Russia's proxy forces launched thousands of attacks on Ukrainian troops in the Donbas.[218] Observers from the Organization for Security and Co-operation in Europe (OSCE), which also includes Ukraine and Russia, reported more than 90,000 ceasefire violations throughout 2021; the vast majority in Russian-controlled territory.[219]

    Fighting in Donbas escalated significantly from 17 February 2022 onwards.[220] The Ukrainians and the pro-Russian separatists each accused the other of attacks.[221][222] There was a sharp increase in artillery shelling by the Russian-led militants in Donbas. Ukraine and its supporters believed this to be an attempt to provoke the Ukrainian army to retaliate, to give Russia a pretext for invading.[223][224][225] Ukraine's president Zelenskyy said that his military would not respond to the provocations.[226] Separatist leaders warned that Ukraine was about to launch an offensive, but gave no evidence, and The Guardian noted that it would be "exceedingly risky" for Ukraine to assault the Donbas while Russian troops were massed on its borders.[226] On 18 February, the Donetsk and Luhansk people's republics ordered emergency evacuations of civilians,[227][228][229] although observers noted that full evacuations would take months.[230] The Russian government intensified its disinformation campaign, with Russian state media airing videos on a nearly hourly basis purporting to show Ukrainian forces attacking Russia.[231] Evidence showed that Russia was staging false flag attacks.[231][232][233]

    On 21 February at 22:35 (UTC+3),[234] Putin announced that the Russian government would diplomatically recognise the Donetsk and Luhansk people's republics.[235] The same evening, Putin directed that Russian troops deploy into Donbas, in what Russia referred to as a "peacekeeping mission".[236][237] On 22 February, the Federation Council unanimously authorised Putin to use military force outside Russia.[238] In response, Zelenskyy ordered the conscription of army reservists;[239] The following day, Ukraine's parliament proclaimed a 30-day nationwide state of emergency and ordered the mobilisation of all reservists.[240][241][242] Russia began to evacuate its embassy in Kyiv.[243]

    On the night of 23 February,[244] Zelenskyy gave a speech in Russian in which he appealed to the citizens of Russia to prevent war.[245][246] He rejected Russia's claims about neo-Nazis and stated that he had no intention of attacking the Donbas.[247]

    Full-scale Russian invasion of Ukraine (2022)

    Main article: 2022 Russian invasion of Ukraine
    See also: Peace negotiations in the Russo-Ukrainian war (2022–present)
    For a chronological guide, see Timeline of the Russo-Ukrainian war (2022–present).

    Russia began a full-scale invasion of Ukraine on the morning of 24 February 2022 in a major escalation of the war.[248] It began following Putin's announcement of a "special military operation" to "demilitarise and denazify" Ukraine.[249][250] Minutes later, missiles and airstrikes hit across Ukraine, including Kyiv, shortly followed by a large ground invasion along multiple fronts.[251][252] Zelenskyy declared martial law and a general mobilisation of all male Ukrainian citizens between 18 and 60, who were banned from leaving the country.[253][254]

    Russian attacks were initially launched on a northern front from Belarus towards Kyiv, a southern front from Crimea, and a south-eastern front from Luhansk and Donetsk and towards Kharkiv.[255][256] In the northern front, amidst heavy losses and strong Ukrainian resistance surrounding Kyiv, Russia's advance stalled in March, and by April its troops retreated. On 8 April, Russia placed its forces in southern and eastern Ukraine under the command of General Aleksandr Dvornikov, and some units withdrawn from the north were redeployed to the Donbas.[257] On 19 April, Russia launched a renewed attack across a 500 kilometres (300 mi) long front extending from Kharkiv to Donetsk and Luhansk.[258] By 13 May, a Ukraine counter-offensive had driven back Russian forces near Kharkiv. By 20 May, Mariupol fell to Russian troops following a prolonged siege of the Azovstal steel works.[259][260] Russian forces continued to bomb both military and civilian targets far from the frontline.[261][262] The war caused the largest refugee and humanitarian crisis within Europe since the Yugoslav Wars in the 1990s;[263][264] the UN described it as the fastest-growing such crisis since World War II.[265] In the first week of the invasion, the UN reported over a million refugees had fled Ukraine; this subsequently rose to over 7,405,590 by 24 September, a reduction from over eight million due to some refugees' return.[266][267]

    The invasion was internationally condemned as a war of aggression.[268][269] A United Nations General Assembly resolution demanded a full withdrawal of Russian forces, the International Court of Justice ordered Russia to suspend military operations and the Council of Europe expelled Russia. Many countries imposed new sanctions, which affected the economies of Russia and the world,[270] and provided humanitarian and military aid to Ukraine.[271] In September 2022, Putin signed a law that would punish anyone who resists conscription with a 10-year prison sentence[272] resulting in an international push to allow asylum for Russians fleeing conscription.[273]

    Ukrainian counteroffensives and stalemate (2022–2023)

    Further information: 2022 Kharkiv counteroffensive and 2022 Kherson counteroffensive

    Ukrainian forces launched counteroffensives in the south in August 2022, and in the northeast in September 2022.
